Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 44151-01 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R–CDTA) 
June 2010 
 
 
 
 
Sharing Knowledge on Community-Driven 
Development in Asia and the Pacific 
(Financed by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Community-driven development (CDD) approaches have been supported as tools for 
addressing poverty, improving governance, and promoting inclusion. Introduced in the mid-
1990s, CDD projects have been implemented in more than 100 countries, including 25 in Asia 
and the Pacific. The World Bank’s 2003 Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper Sourcebook1 defines 
CDD as an approach that gives control over planning decisions and investment resources for 
local development projects to community groups. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) adopts 
five  elements  in  defining  CDD:  a  community  focus,  participatory  planning  and  design, 
community  control  of  resources,  community  involvement  in  implementation,  and  use  of 
community-based participatory monitoring and evaluation to ensure downward accountability to 
the community. 
 
2.  Since 2001, ADB has financed 80 projects with CDD characteristics throughout Asia and 
the Pacific. Through case studies and exchanges among policy makers, members of academia, 
civil  society  organizations,  and  developing  member  country  (DMC)  representatives,  the 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Supporting  Community-Driven  Development  in  Developing 
Member Countries2 confirmed the following benefits of the approach: (i) infrastructure projects of 
equal or better quality are delivered at less cost than other government projects; (ii) there is high 
participation of women and the poor; (iii) there is lower corruption; and (iii) there is high potential 
for generating employment, especially during economic downturns. Recent forums sponsored 
by  the  TA  confirm  such  benefits.3 The  same  forums,  however,  emphasize  the  need  for 
additional  support  and  the  establishment  of  a  network  of  practitioners  for  knowledge 
management and shared learning, especially in new and upcoming frontiers of environmental 
protection,  achievement  of  Millennium  Development  Goals,  and  local  governance,  and  in 
scaling up the approach.   
 
3.  A study by ADB in 2006 cited the high potential of CDD approaches for scaling up, but 
cautioned against universal approaches and emphasized the need to pay attention to contexts 
and appropriate designs.4 The study, citing various evaluations of ADB and partners, also 
emphasized the need for partnerships with practitioners and institutions—such as the World 
Bank and other institutions—on CDD design and implementation, which could take the form of 
networks, joint learning events, staff exchange programs and joint missions, and joint research. 
In response, this TA project has been designed to build the capacity of DMCs to introduce or 
scale  up  community  development  operations  through  (i)  research  and  documentation,  (ii) 
establishing a knowledge hub for CDD, and (iii) supporting a CDD network of practitioners. This 
TA paper defines the output, methodology, and key activities of the project. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
 
                                                 
1  World Bank. 2003. The World Bank PRSP Sourcebook. Washington, DC (Chapter 9 – Community Driven

2  ADB.  2007.  Technical  Assistance  for  Supporting  Community-Driven  Development  in  Developing  Member 
Countries. Manila. 
3  Forum on Community-Driven Development and Strategy 2020, Manila, December 2008; and the International

II.  ISSUES 
4.  Lessons  drawn  from  the  TA  for  Supporting  Community-Driven  Development  in 
Developing Member Countries emphasize the need for supporting knowledge sharing among a 
network of practitioners on community development approaches so as to improve the capacity 
of DMCs for scaling up. While much has been done to document learning from different models, 
much more can be gained through formal cooperation and networking among practitioners to 
share experiences and innovations. In addition, what may have worked in one setting may not 
be applicable to another. This was emphasized at the International Conference on Community-
Driven Development and Rural Poverty Alleviation, held on 18–19 October 2009 in Beijing, 
where participants raised the value of networking and cooperation, especially in knowledge and 
experience sharing. CDD projects in Asia and the Pacific have benefitted from exchanges and 
networking.6 Designs of these projects are context-specific, with regard having been given to 
what  worked  and  did  not  work  in  other  countries.  There  is  thus  high  value  in  supporting 
continuing exchanges on the approach. There is a large amount of information from (i) research 
and lessons gained from experience in CDD,7 (ii) information on what worked and what did not; 
and  (iii)  responses  to  the  common  challenges  of  elite  capture,  anticorruption,  adaptive 
management schemes, and governance issues. This body of knowledge constitutes a wealth of 
information  that  can  create  greater  impact  if  organized  and  made  accessible  to  various 
stakeholders. This effort can also facilitate cross-fertilization of initiatives and inform policy 
decisions, programming, and project design.   
 
5.  There is also a need to support local development platforms that can serve multiple 
objectives. Experience has shown that, once a CDD platform exists, it can be used for multiple 
development objectives, including (i) improved infrastructure and service delivery, (ii) improved 
livelihood opportunities, (iii) better climate adaptation and natural resource management, and (iv) 
more recently, as a safety net and social service delivery mechanism. CDD has contributed to 
the development of local platforms linked to decentralization efforts and reconstruction and post-
conflict interventions. While most elements of the approach are the same, their application in 
specific situations and countries will vary. Capturing experience and practice, through more 
research  and  documentation,  to  produce  and  organize  community  development  tools  and 
learning materials will contribute to the introduction of appropriate models or the scaling up of 
existing models throughout Asia and the Pacific. Areas of special interest for focused studies 
include integrating with decentralization initiatives, institutionalizing fiscal transfer arrangements 
and accountability frameworks, and improving gender outcomes.  
 
6.  However, CDD approaches have had mixed results and CDD does not apply in all 
settings.  The  use  of  CDD  approaches  for  microfinance,  for  example,  was  generally 
unsuccessful in the first round in Indonesia. The same approaches in the Philippines, however, 
have met with more success. Some national (and international) development priorities—such as 
HIV/AIDS, climate change adaptation, conflict prevention, and large-scale infrastructure—do not 
always coincide with community priorities, making it difficult to address them through community 
approaches.  Urban  development  and  slum  upgrading,  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise 
development, microfinance, and onlending projects are areas where community development 
approaches have had mixed results. Fiduciary aspects of CDD were raised as critical issues, for 
example, in urban projects in Indonesia. Documentation of past and current initiatives can

of Social Services (KALAHI-CIDSS) projects and the People's Republic of China's (PRC) CDD pilots.

contribute to a better understanding of appropriate approaches and identification of design 
factors to consider in these areas.   
 
7.  Among the models that the TA will review are the Korean Saemul Undung experience, 
Indonesia's Kecamatan Development Program, the Philippines' Kapitbisig Laban sa Kahirapan 
– Comprehensive and Integrated Delivery of Social Services (KALAHI-CIDSS), and the CDD 
pilots in the People's Republic of China (PRC).   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  This TA will build the capacity of DMCs to scale up community development operations 
through (i) research and documentation of lessons learned, on selected themes;8 (ii) setting up 
a knowledge and learning hub and an e-library of resources on community development to 
share and disseminate information among practitioners, DMCs, and development partners; and 
(iii) support for a network of practitioners9 by helping to establish and strengthen informal and 
formal community development networks within ADB and between ADB and external agencies.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will contribute to more inclusive economic growth in DMCs stemming from 
increased demand for and application of community development approaches. The TA will 
strengthen  the  capacity  of  DMCs  to  apply  community  development  approaches  through 
knowledge sharing and cooperation among participating countries and institutions. This effort is 
expected to result in greater demand for such interventions. The outcome will be increased 
awareness and improved readiness of DMCs to design and implement community development 
projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will support research in selected areas of community development. From the 
research, operational approaches to situations of fragility, weak governance, exclusion, or post-
conflict will be developed and, to the extent applicable, integrated into various initiatives for 
mainstreaming  community  development  in  DMC  operations.  Thematic  areas  of  gender, 
inclusion, monitoring and evaluation, and measuring results and impact, among others, will also 
be studied. Country-specific or regional approaches in community development in new areas, 
such as urban development, climate change adaptation, HIV/AIDS, and such areas as may be 
identified by the network, will be explored and/or supported through studies and technical inputs. 
The TA, in coordination with regional operations departments and network participants, will 
identify priority areas for further study during implementation and facilitate coordination among 
development partners in the region. 
 
11.  The experience of at least four countries (the PRC, Indonesia, Republic of Korea, and 
the Philippines) in community development will be documented, and tools will be compiled for 
dissemination  to  DMCs  and  development  partners.  These  country  experience  include  the 
Saemul Undung movement of the Republic of Korea, the Kecamatan Development Project in 
Indonesia, the KALAHI-CIDSS CDD project in the Philippines, and the CDD experience in the 
                                                 
8  The indicative list of areas for study include the Saemul Undung experience, CDD in urban settings, CDD and 
climate adaptation, gender, and local governance. 
9  An informal network of CDD of practitioners exists in ADB. The TA intends to work with external practitioners, 
including civil society organizations, DMCs, project managers of ongoing CDD projects, practitioners in other 
development organizations, academia, and local governments.

4  
PRC. Experience in the Pacific will also be included upon expression of interest by countries in 
that  region.  The  countries  were  chosen  based  on  their previous  experience in  community 
development, their participation in a previous TA project on CDD, and their willingness to 
participate in this new initiative. 
 
12.  The  TA  will  foster  knowledge  in  community  development  and  provide  learning 
opportunities on priority development topics. Information and tools gathered and knowledge 
products developed will be disseminated through a learning hub managed by the network of 
practitioners and ADB. These include practical and cost-effective tools for measuring results, 
real-time data gathering, and similar tools to ensure effectiveness of the approach. The hub will 
sponsor and coordinate learning and knowledge events, workshops and seminars, and online 
exchanges to address the needs for information and learning of the network. The hub will also 
serve as a regional resource center of information on lessons learned, tool kits in use, expertise, 
and other similar resources. To support the hub, a community development portal will be 
developed and maintained. At the end of the TA, it is envisioned that the hub will be jointly 
managed by network members supported under the next activity. The hub will be open for use 
by members of the network, DMC officials and practitioners, ADB staff, and civil society groups. 
 
13.  The TA will also strengthen or formalize existing networks in community development 
and facilitate interaction among representatives from academia, policy makers, researchers, 
and development practitioners, and among ADB operational departments. The network will 
support DMCs in the development of their country-specific community development models and 
enhance ADB’s ability to respond to their needs more effectively. Joint activities in project 
development and knowledge and resource sharing will be identified and pursued. Among the 
networks to be supported are the participants and resource speakers at the recent Beijing 
International  Community  Driven  Development  (CDD)  Conference,  the  internal  ADB  CDD 
network, and CDD practitioners in DMCs.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  to  be 
administered by ADB. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA project, which will be managed by ADB’s 
Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development Division of the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department. A team of Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development 
Division  staff,  including  two  professional  members  of  staff,  one  national  officer,  and  two 
operations assistants, will coordinate and manage the consultants’ activities and consolidate 
their outputs. The project will be carried out over 16 months, from April 2010 to August 2011.  
 
16.  The  TA  will  require  a  total  of  20  person-months  of  consulting  services.  Three 
international consultants (total of 12 person-months) and two national consultants (total of 8 
person-months)  based  in  Manila  will  form  the  core  TA  consulting  team.  The  international 
consultants will have expertise in community-driven development, knowledge management, and 
social development. The national consultants will have expertise in information technology and 
conference management. Country-based national consultants will be engaged to undertake 
country-level studies for 10 months. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).

5
Disbursements  will  conform  to  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (May 
2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The TA will disseminate learning and good practices through a website and several 
workshops and learning events, bringing together participating countries, development partners, 
and civil society organizations.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for Sharing 
Knowledge on Community-Driven Development in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Three individual international consultants (total of 12 person-months) and two national 
consultants (total of 8 person-months) based in Manila will form the core technical assistance 
(TA) team. The international consultants will have expertise in community-driven development 
(CDD), knowledge management, and social development. The national consultants will have 
expertise in information technology and conference management. Thematic studies will be 
undertaken by the international social development consultant with expertise in gender and 
urban development (4 person-months). Country-based consultants will be engaged to undertake 
country-level studies for 10 person-months. Each consultant will be responsible for finalizing his 
or her outputs in close coordination with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) team leader and 
key stakeholders in regional operations departments and developing member countries (DMCs). 
The selection and finalization of study areas, including their scope and methodology, will be 
done in close collaboration with regional operations departments.  
 
A.  International Consultants (12 person-months, intermittent) 
2.  The  international  consultants  will  have  undertaken  similar  work  in  the  past  with  a 
minimum of 10 years work experience in developing countries and institutions similar to ADB.  
 
1.  Community-Driven Development Consultant 
3.   The  CDD  consultant  will  have  a  degree  in  social  science,  political  science,  public 
administration, or other relevant social development field. He or she will have at least 10 years 
experience  in  poverty  reduction  and  participatory  development,  including  experience  in 
designing and implementing CDD-type projects in Asia and the Pacific. The consultant should 
have a good conceptual understanding of community development and local development. 
Familiarity  with  multilateral  development  bank  lending  schemes  is  mandatory.  The  CDD 
consultant will be primarily responsible for overseeing and preparing the thematic studies, and 
leading the activities of the network. The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  undertake a stakeholder mapping and analysis of potential players who can 
contribute to and benefit from the TA; 
(ii)  consult with operations department staff and network partners to identify areas of 
study, including a list of projects that can be the subject of case studies;  
(iii)  undertake  a  desk  review  of  literature  and  programs  on  CDD  in  the  region, 
including  studies  undertaken,  tools  and  manuals  developed,  and  past  and 
ongoing country programs involving CDD, and, with the assistance of a national 
consultant  and  the  information  technology  consultant,  develop  a  web-based 
knowledge-sharing system on CDD; 
(iv)  provide guidance to other consultants on the development and finalization of 
thematic and country studies; 
(v)  travel to DMCs concerned and provide technical inputs and/or facilitation support 
to counterparts and ADB project teams in preparing the studies;  
(vi)  lead in the preparation of a study on the opportunities for synergies between 
CDD approaches and local development; 
(vii)  prepare a final report and a consolidation of all thematic and country studies, in 
collaboration with other consultants; 
(viii)  attend and make presentations in regional or national workshops to disseminate 
the results of the TA; 
(ix)  act as a resource person for ADB and DMCs on CDD;

10  Appendix 3 
 
(x)  liaise with other development and funding agencies and governments to promote 
coordination and consistency with respect to the approach and recommendations 
of the study; and  
(xi)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA.  
 
2.  Knowledge Management Consultant 
4.  The knowledge management consultant will have extensive experience in knowledge 
management, dissemination of information, and the use of information and communication 
technology in information and knowledge management. He or she will be primarily responsible 
for setting up the knowledge hub and making it operational, and will be in charge of organizing 
knowledge-sharing events. The consultant will also  
 
(i)  coordinate  and  collaborate  with  the  knowledge  management  unit  of  ADB  in 
developing and executing the knowledge management work plan of the TA; 
(ii)  examine best practices in knowledge sharing and management and recommend 
appropriate approaches for the TA; 
(iii)  lead and design knowledge events and preparation of materials and activities for 
DMCs, development partners, and ADB staff on CDD practices and issues in the 
region; 
(iv)  prepare a plan for the regional dissemination and management of knowledge on 
CDD, using primarily web-based forums and venues;  
(v)  liaise with other development and funding agencies and governments to promote 
coordination and consistency; and 
(vi)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA. 
 
3.  Social Development Consultant 
5.  The social development consultant (gender and participatory development) will have at 
least 8 years experience in local participatory development and gender and development, with 
an educational background in development studies, social development, public administration, 
or related fields. The consultant will primarily be responsible for two studies on gender and 
urban approaches to CDD, and will 
 
(i)  consult with operations department staff and network members to identify areas 
of study, including a list of projects that can be the subject of case studies;  
(ii)  in coordination with the CDD specialist and the ADB team leader, undertake a 
desk review of literature and programs on CDD in the region, including studies 
undertaken,  tools  and  manuals  developed,  and  past  and  ongoing  country 
programs involving CDD, and, with the assistance of a national consultant and 
the information technology consultant, develop a web-based knowledge-sharing 
system on CDD; 
(iii)  lead in the preparation of at least two studies on CDD and improving gender and 
development outcomes, and review CDD approaches in urban settings, distilling 
lessons and practical implications in project design and policy reform;  
(iv)  attend and make presentations in regional or national workshops to disseminate 
TA results; 
(v)  assisted by a national consultant, collect information and tools and update ADB's 
database;

Appendix 3  11 
(vi)  liaise with other development and funding agencies and governments to promote 
coordination and consistency with respect to the approach and recommendations 
of the study; and  
(vii)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA.  
 
B.  National Consultants: Information and Communication Technology and 
Knowledge Management (8 person-months, intermittent) 
  
6.   The  national  consultants  will  be  based  in  Manila  and  perform  tasks  under  the 
supervision of staff of ADB’s Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development Division of 
the Regional and Sustainable Development Department. The consultants will 
 
(i)  support the setting up of web-based learning and knowledge-sharing tools for the 
TA; 
(ii)  manage e-learning events and facilitate online networking and other means to 
enhance knowledge exchange; 
(iii)  participate in and document meetings and workshops;  
(iv)  update and improve the CDD project database; 
(v)  collect  key  documents  and  data  related  to  CDD  project  preparation  and 
implementation and input them into the database, including directory of resource 
persons  and  consultants,  regional  institutes, nongovernment  organizations  or 
civil society organizations involved in CDD, and other multilateral and bilateral aid 
agencies, and knowledge products produced by ADB and others; 
(vi)  support the preparation of studies by collecting and processing key documents 
and data; 
(vii)  provide logistical and administrative support for training, conference, knowledge 
exchange, and the conduct of studies; 
(viii)  assist  the  team  leader  in  overall  TA  administration  and  the  logistics  for  the 
studies, workshops, and publications; and 
(ix)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA.  
 
C.  National Consultants in Participating Member Countries (10 person-months) 
 
7.  For at least four participating member countries, a national consultant will be selected 
and recruited to support the TA and the international consultants during the TA implementation. 
Each consultant will have a good understanding of the community development experience in 
the country where he or she would be assigned to work. The consultants will 
 
(i)  lead  in  developing  country  case  studies  of  community  development  in  the 
respective country, with focus on innovations and their application in regions or 
subregions of Asia and the Pacific; 
(ii)  assist international consultants in consolidating information and drafting the final 
country papers; 
(iii)  review previous country studies and available literature, including those by other 
international agencies and private entities and nongovernment and civil society 
organizations on scaling up CDD; 
(iv)  review the different institutional, policy, and legal environments supporting or 
deterring  scaling  up  of  community  development  practice  in  the  counties  or 
subregions;

(v)  assist the team leader and international consultants in collecting study-related 
data, drafting case study reports, and preparing presentations of the reports in 
the regional workshop or conference; and 
(vi)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA.
